posts.body:
Sister Rosetta Tharpe

“Can’t no man play like me.”

[an album cover]

Sister Rosetta Tharpe (1915-1973) was an American musician. A primarily gospel artist, her unique contributions to music were foundational to the origins of rock and roll. She’s been called “the original soul sister” and “the Godmother of rock and roll”, and nearly every great rock-and-roll musician has cited her as an influence.

Tharpe was born in Arkansas. Her parents were cotton pickers and musicians, and Tharpe grew up in a church that encouraged musical expression of devotion, including for women. Tharpe began performing in church at the age of 4.

[Tharpe onstage]

Starting at the age of 6, she travelled with her mother’s evangelical troupe before settling in Chicago for a few years. When she was 23, she and her mother moved to New York City where she began her career as a recording artist.

Tharpe’s first recorded songs, all gospel, were instant hits and Tharpe became a sensation overnight. Her music was new–it mixed religious lyrics with secular-sounding music, and it was shocking to many traditionalists, but it also allowed her music to be appreciated by a secular audience.

[a depiction of Tharpe]

She began to play in secular nightclubs, sometimes with showgirls, which further distanced her from the gospel community. Already under fire for playing guitar as a woman, her skills and determination put her under fire from all sides. Still, she grew in fame and popularity.

She continued performing, solo and in group acts with other Black women. She performed for soldiers during World War II, toured Europe in the 60s, and managed to get 25,000 people to pay to attend her (third) wedding.

Many of her contemporaries also suspected that she was romantically and sexually involved with Marie Knight, a gospel and R&B singer, though both women denied this.

[Tharpe at a microphone]

She died in 1973 from a stroke in Philadelphia and is buried there. She had been due to record the following day. Tharpe started performing at the age of 4 and did not stop up until her death.

Her unique guitar style blended urban blues, folk arrangements, swing, and gospel lyrics. Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Little Richard, Aretha Franklin, Jerry Lee Lewis, Isaac Hayes, Tina Turner, Meat Loaf, Neil Sedaka, Chuck Berry, Carl Perkins, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck, and Keith Richards all cite her as a prominent influence.

[Tharpe’s induction into the 2018 Rock & Roll Hall of Fame]

In 2018, Tharpe was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

Songs to Listen To

1. “Strange Things Happening Every Day” (1944)

2. “Up Above My Head, I Hear Music in the Air” (1948)

3. “Down by the Riverside” (1944)

posts.body:
Cecilia Payne

Cecilia Helena Payne-Gaposchkin (1900-1979) was the woman who discovered what the universe was made of.

[Payne]

Born in England, she was highly educated from a young age but faced continuous struggles due to her sex. Her mother interrupted her education at the age of 12 for the sake of her brother’s school. She then attended St. Mary’s College, Paddington, which did not provide her with the scientific and mathematic education she desired. She switched to St Paul’s Girls’ School, where she was encouraged to study music. But Payne was determined to study science.

She received a full scholarship to Newnham College, Cambridge University. She completed her studies in physics and chemistry but Cambridge did not award degrees to women. However, her time in university did allow her to find an interest in astronomy.

[A photograph of Payne]

Jobs in academia for women in the U.K. were limited, so in 1923 Payne left for America. She began her graduate studies at Harvard University, and was the first person–man or woman–to earn a PhD in astronomy from Radcliffe College of Harvard University.

Using ionization theory developed by Meghnad Saha, an Indian physicist, she wrote Stellar Atmospheres; A Contribution to the Observational Study of High Temperature in the Reversing Layers of Stars in 1925. Her thesis showed that stars were overwhelmingly made of hydrogen, making it by far the most abundant element in the universe.

This contradicted the current scientific consensus, so astronomer Henry Norris Russell convinced her to drop her conclusion. Of course, science and history would prove Payne right and Russell wrong–almost immediately. Russell himself confirmed her theory with a different procedure, which he then published. While Russell did acknowledge Payne’s work, he was mistakenly credited for her discovery for years after.

Payne continued to work in astronomy at Harvard, though for many years she was forced to take positions well below her actual job description and expertise because roles were not available to women. Eventually, however, Donald Menzel became Director of the Harvard College Observatory and gave her the accolades due. In 1956, she became the first woman to be promoted to full professor from within at Harvard’s Faculty of Arts and Sciences. She also became the first woman to head any department at all of Harvard.

[Payne doing research]

Her students included many famous and notable astronomers, including noted female astronomer Helen Sawyer Hogg. She also supervised Frank Kameny, an astronomer and one of the foremost figures of the American gay rights movements in the 1960s.

Upon her retirement, she became Professor Emerita of Harvard University in 1967, and remain active in research for many years. She died in 1979, having successfully rewritten our fundamental understanding of the universe.

On This Day In History

August 10th, 1680, the Pueblo Revolt of Indigenous Puebloans against Spanish colonizers begins. It lasts 11 days and ends in a decisive Puebloan victory, including the expulsion of all 2,000 Spanish settlers.

posts.body:
Nellie Bly

TERFS/RADFEM DNI

Elizabeth Cochrane Seaman (1864-1922), known by her pen name Nellie Bly, was…well, she was a lot of things.

[Bly before her around-the-world journey]

She famously successfully travelled around the entire world in just 72 days, setting a world record. She also invented modern-day investigative journalism and exposed conditions at mental institutions, ushering in widespread reform.

Born in Pennsylvania to a wealthy laborer-turned-landowner and his second wife, Bly was one of 15 children. Ambitious from a young age, she attempted to go to college but dropped out due to a lack of funds.

[Bly]

Her newspaper career started with her passionate response to a column in the Pittsburgh Dispatch that argued girls were ‘Good For’ bearing and raising children. Her writing was so excellent she was offered a job, where she declared all newspapers had an obligation to write about ordinary people. At just 18 years of age, she was commissioned to write an article about the lives of women.

She began publishing a series of articles about social issues, often going undercover. Her first article was about how divorce laws affected women, in one of her others, she worked in a factory to write about child labour and unsafe working conditions.

Her writing was so effective that corporate pressure eventually forced the Pittsburgh Dispatch to stop publishing her series, though her editor thought her writing was excellent.

Instead, she was told to cover social and cultural events. Bly immediately began to make trouble. She traveled to Mexico, from where she was deported after just six months after writing about the poverty and political corruption.

[A 21-year-old Bly in Mexico]

She was then recruited by Pulitzer to write for the New York World where she pioneered investigative journalism. Her far-reaching topics included poverty, housing, and labor.

In 1887, Bly feigned insanity in order to be sent to, and report on, The Blackwell Island insane asylum, named the Women’s Lunatic Asylum. She stayed for 10 days and wrote a blistering report on the abusive treatment of the doctors, the lack of sanitary conditions, and the numerous 'patients’ who were suffering from physical illnesses or had been placed there by malicious family members. Her writing kicked off massive reforms in treatment of mental illnesses and disabilities.

[A newspaper clipping reading:“Behind Asylum Bars. The Mystery of the Unknown Insane Girl. Remarkable Story of the Successful Impersonation of Insanity. How Nellie Brown Deceived Judges, Reporters and Medical Experts. She Tells Her Story of How She Passed at Bellevue Hospital.]

In 1889, Bly read Around the World in Eighty Days by Jules Verne and rather felt she could do better. She convinced Pulitzer to finance her trip to circle the globe, and accomplished it in 72 days, 6 hours, 11 minutes, and 14 seconds, setting the world record.

Bly retired from journalism when she got married in 1895 and, after the death of her husband, took over both of his companies. Bly introduced a series of reforms to support the rights and needs of her workers, including schemes for healthcare, exercise, and education.

She came out of retirement when World War One broke out. She immediately travelled to the Eastern Front and began reporting on the war for the New York Journal American.

[Bly and a Polish military officer]

Bly died of pneumonia in 1922 and was buried in the Bronx. Her legacy remains as one of the greatest journalists of all time.

There are other things I did not touch on for brevity’s sake: her work with the Woman Suffrage Procession, the time she was arrested for accused espionage, her inventions. She was one of the greatest people of the 19th and 20th centuries, and her mark on journalism, labor movements, disability rights, and women’s rights will continue to impact us all.

[a stamp of Bly]

She famously successfully travelled around the entire world in just 72 days, setting a world record. She also invented modern-day investigative journalism and exposed conditions at mental institutions, ushering in widespread reform.

Born in Pennsylvania to a wealthy laborer-turned-landowner and his second wife, Bly was one of 15 children. Ambitious from a young age, she attempted to go to college but dropped out due to a lack of funds.

[Bly]

Her newspaper career started with her passionate response to a column in the Pittsburgh Dispatch that argued girls were ‘Good For’ bearing and raising children. Her writing was so excellent she was offered a job, where she declared all newspapers had an obligation to write about ordinary people. At just 18 years of age, she was commissioned to write an article about the lives of women.

She began publishing a series of articles about social issues, often going undercover. Her first article was about how divorce laws affected women, in one of her others, she worked in a factory to write about child labour and unsafe working conditions.

Her writing was so effective that corporate pressure eventually forced the Pittsburgh Dispatch to stop publishing her series, though her editor thought her writing was excellent.

Instead, she was told to cover social and cultural events. Bly immediately began to make trouble. She traveled to Mexico, from where she was deported after just six months after writing about the poverty and political corruption.

[A 21-year-old Bly in Mexico]

She was then recruited by Pulitzer to write for the New York World where she pioneered investigative journalism. Her far-reaching topics included poverty, housing, and labor.

In 1887, Bly feigned insanity in order to be sent to, and report on, The Blackwell Island insane asylum, named the Women’s Lunatic Asylum. She stayed for 10 days and wrote a blistering report on the abusive treatment of the doctors, the lack of sanitary conditions, and the numerous 'patients’ who were suffering from physical illnesses or had been placed there by malicious family members. Her writing kicked off massive reforms in treatment of mental illnesses and disabilities.

[A newspaper clipping reading:“Behind Asylum Bars. The Mystery of the Unknown Insane Girl. Remarkable Story of the Successful Impersonation of Insanity. How Nellie Brown Deceived Judges, Reporters and Medical Experts. She Tells Her Story of How She Passed at Bellevue Hospital.]

In 1889, Bly read Around the World in Eighty Days by Jules Verne and rather felt she could do better. She convinced Pulitzer to finance her trip to circle the globe, and accomplished it in 72 days, 6 hours, 11 minutes, and 14 seconds, setting the world record.

Bly retired from journalism when she got married in 1895 and, after the death of her husband, took over both of his companies. Bly introduced a series of reforms to support the rights and needs of her workers, including schemes for healthcare, exercise, and education.

She came out of retirement when World War One broke out. She immediately travelled to the Eastern Front and began reporting on the war for the New York Journal American.

[Bly and a Polish military officer]

Bly died of pneumonia in 1922 and was buried in the Bronx. Her legacy remains as one of the greatest journalists of all time.

There are other things I did not touch on for brevity’s sake: her work with the Woman Suffrage Procession, the time she was arrested for accused espionage, her inventions. She was one of the greatest people of the 19th and 20th centuries, and her mark on journalism, labor movements, disability rights, and women’s rights will continue to impact us all.

[a stamp of Bly]

tags: International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples
posts.body:
Tecumseh and Tenskwatawa

August 9th is the International Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples

Tecumseh (1769-1813) and his younger brother Tenskwatawa (1775-1836) were Native American leaders. Of the Shawnee, an Algonquin-speaking group in the Northern Atlantic Woodlands and the Great Lakes region, the brothers organized the military, religious, and cultural resistance of many tribes against the United States expansion.

[A painting of Tecumseh]

Tecumseh was born in Shawnee land that was being lost to encroaching Americans in a series of military battles, including one which killed Tecumseh’s father when he was still a child. He was a war leader who fought against the Americans for many years.

[A painting of Tenskwatawa]

In 1805, Tenskwatawa (oftentimes called ‘The Prophet’ or 'The Shawnee Prophet’) began to grow as a religious and political leader. He denounced the Americans and their religion and led a movement of spiritual purification that promoted a rejection of American culture and religion, a return to traditional ways, and unity among all Native American tribes.

In 1808, Tecumseh and Tenskwatawa founded Prophetstown, which quickly became the center of a large, multi-tribal community. Tecumseh traveled, spreading Tenskwatawa’s religious message and urging a dedicated, unified resistance.

This resistance was religious and cultural; including rejections of Christianity and European-style agriculture, economic; including rejections of selling land unless all tribes agreed on it; political; including inter-tribal political discussions, and military; including an armed resistance.

Tecumseh’s Confederacy, as it became called, allied with the British in the War of 1812. Despite the strength of the brothers’ message, Tecumseh was killed at the Battle of the Thames in 1813. The Confederacy fell apart the American government seized the lands he had been protecting. After his brother’s death, Tenskwatawa retained some minor influence, enough that he represented the Shawnee in their forced relocation by the American government. Tenskwatawa died in 1836.

Though their efforts were ultimately unsuccessful, the strength of their message and their resistance has transformed Tecumseh and Tesnkwatawa into folk heroes, among both the Native Americans the fought to inspire and the White colonists who they fought against. Their actions are one of the most celebrated and powerful stories of Native American history.

“I want nothing but death.”

-Austen, Jane (1775-1817)

Last words of famed author Jane Austen, spoken to sister Cassandra on her deathbed. Cause of death: Addison’s disease.

Source: Last Words of Notable People by William B. Brahms

posts.body:
Charles Frederick Worth

The Father of Fashion, the Head of the House of Worth.

Charles Frederick Worth (1825-1895) was an English fashion designer, generally considered to be the first fashion designer (by modern definitions) in the world.

Worth was born to a poor family in a small market town in England. His father abandoned his mother, Worth, and his four siblings (only one other of which survived til adulthood)–after draining all their money. Worth began working at age 11 in a printer’s shop, but after only a year he moved to London to begin his apprenticeship in a department store. Before he even turned 20, he was working at a leading British textile store.

[a fancy dress constume]

At the age of 21, Worth moved to Paris. Though he spoke absolutely no French at the time, he quickly became a sales assistant at a fabric firm that sold expensive silks and cashmeres to high society, including the dressmakers at the Parisian court.

[an evening dress]

Worth began sewing dresses–first simple, but eventually gained enough success and popular to open a dress department. His dresses became famous for their beauty and craftsmanship, and were displayed in The Great Exhibition of 1851 in London and the Exposition Universelle of 1855 in Paris.

[a peacock dress]

He quickly found success making ball dresses for the princesses of Europe, but in 1860, he became the favored dressmaker for Empress Eugénie of the French Empire. She ordered 250 dresses from Worth for the opening of the Suez Canal in Egypt.

[an evening dress]

His dresses became widely known and recognizable–one could tell a Worth dress just by looking at it. He also changed the social dynamics–rather than dressmakers doing in-home fittings, his salon became a social hub of the wealthy and well-connected. Worth also, famously, outright told his clients (noblewomen, mainly) if he thought their fashion choices were ugly.

[an evening dress]

His fashion house has over 1,200 staff at its peak sewing dresses, mixing hand sewing and machine sewing for custom orders and showcases. He had two major innovations: he narrowed the silhouette of the crinoline–then large enough to be a physical hindrance to women–and he invented a walking skirt with a hemline at ankle length. The scandal!

[a walking dress]

He died at age 69 in Paris of pneumonia. More than just a dressmaker, he completely changed the marketing and selling of dresses in the fashion industry. He, unique for his time, viewed fashion as an art foremost, creating dresses that were uniquely his. He was the first designer to put labels in his clothes.

[an evening dress]

He had two major innovations: he narrowed the silhouette of the crinoline–then large enough to be a physical hindrance to women–and he invented a walking skirt with a hemline at ankle length. The scandal!

[a walking dress]

He died at age 69 in Paris of pneumonia. More than just a dressmaker, he completely changed the marketing and selling of dresses in the fashion industry. He, unique for his time, viewed fashion as an art foremost, creating dresses that were uniquely his. He was the first designer to put labels in his clothes.

[an evening dress]

posts.body:
Pachacuti Inca Yupanqui

The 9th Sapa Inca (king) of the Kingdom of Cusco, Pachacuti (1318-1471/1472) transformed it into the Inca Empire and led a massive imperial conquest across the South American continent.

[Pachacuti]

Pachacuti actually was not the crown prince–that was his older brother. But he showed an early aptitude for laws, politics, and language, as well as courage and conquest. When his father and older brother fled the city from invades, Pachacuti organized a successful defence and in 1438 was named successor over his brother.

He also started the Inti Raymi-rata, a festival to honor the Incan sun god, Inti. One of the foremost gods in the Incan pantheon and a patron of the Empire, the royal family was often said to be his descendants. Pachacuti in particular was considered the son of the Sun.

[Pachacuti worshipping Inti]

Supposedly at the behest of Inti, Pachacuti led a series of conquest against his neighbours, which he folded into the Empire.

He was also a noted poet and an excellent statesman. His rule over his numerous conquered lands was stable. He is also responsible for the mountain city Machu Picchu, constructed for Pachacuti’s personal use. Machu Picchu is now considered on of the New Seven Wonders of the World and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

[Machu Picchu, a city in the mountains]

Pachacuti died in 1471 due to illness, leaving his son, Thupa Inca, to take over peacefully.

posts.body:
John Snow

“You and I may not live to see the day, and my name may be forgotten when it comes, but the time will arrive when great outbreaks of cholera will be things of the past; and it is the knowledge of the way in which the disease is propagated which will cause them to disappear.”

John Snow (1813-1858) was an English physician and the Father of Epidemiology, the study of how diseases spread. His work was essential to deal with the deadly cholera outbreaks of his time and remains foundational in our understanding of how to prevent diseases like COVID-19 from spreading.

Snow was the eldest of nine children born to a working father in a poor, polluted part of York, England. He showed an early aptitude for math and education, and earned his MD as a surgeon and general practitioner. He had particular interests in anesthesiology and respiratory diseases, and was one of the first physicians to calculate appropriate dosages of anesthetics used for his patients curing surgeon.

Still, the dreaded outbreaks of deadly cholera, at the time thought to be from polluted, miasmic air, was a concern for every physician at the time. Germ theory had not been developed, so miasma theory was the standard, but Snow was dubious. He spoke with the families of those who had died in the 1854 Broad Street cholera outbreak and was able to trace the disease to a single water pump.

Snow could not actually find any evidence of what was supposedly infectious in the water–microscopes were not advanced enough to see bacteria like Vibrio cholerae–but his evidence on transmission patterns was so convincing the city closed the pump anyways.

posts.body:
Fatima al-Fihri

The founder of the oldest university in the world.

Fatima al-Fihri was an Arabian woman who lived from around 800 CE-880 CE. Born in Qayrawān, Abbasid Caliphate (modern-day Tunisia), her family immigrated to Fez in the Idrisid dynasty (modern-day Morocco).

[the courtyard and minaret of the University]

Her father became wealthy in Fez and, upon his death, left his wealth to Fatima and her sister, Maryam. The two sisters went on to found and finance two of the most famous mosques in Fez.

[the door to the library, the oldest continuously-running library in the world]

Fatima built the al-Qarawiyyan Mosque, now called the University of al-Qarawiyyin, which began as a religious center for immigrants in the city. It became only of the most well-regarded madrasas, a place of education. It continued to function for over a thousand years. In 1963 CE, it became a state university. In 2012, it had over 8,000 students.

Maryam used her share of the money to found al-Andalus (named for the Andalusi refugees who used it–the Muslim people expelled from the Iberian Peninsula). It also provided education and libraries, like the Al-Qarawiyyin, but never reached the educational status of a university like its sister building.

[walls inside the library]

This story’s validity has been fairly questioned. The first written mention of the sisters is by Ibn Abi Zar, a historian who lived 500 years after the founding of the mosques, so it’s entirely possible the entire story is a legend.

posts.body:
Nampeyo

One of the finest pottery artists in history, Nampeyo [also: Num-pa-pu/Nampaya] (1859 or 1860-1942) was a Hopi-Tewa artisan who spearheaded the Sikyátki Revival, an artistic movement reviving the styles of her ancestors’ hundreds of years ago, before European contact on the Americas.

A noted Native American artist who achieved worldwide fame, one of her pots set the record for Southwest American Indian pottery when it sold for $350,000 in 2010–68 years after her death!

The daughter of a Tewa Puebloan of the Corn Clan, her father was of the Snake Clan. Due to matrilineal descent, Nampeyo was also born into the Tewa Corn Clan on Hopi lands.

She never learned to read or write, but learned to make and sell pottery from her paternal grandmother. As she worked, she became interested in ancient pottery. Nampeyo and her husband Lesou worked with the archaeologist J. Walter Fewkes on the excavation of the Sikyátki ruins.

[An unearthed Sikyátki pot with a moth design Nampeyo used as a reference]

The Sikyátki archeological site was inhabited by the Hopi from the 14th to 17th century, and left behind a many ceramic potsherds from which Nampeyo drew her inspiration.

Inspired by these designs, Nampeyo went on to create some of the most beautiful pottery in the art world. Her designs were elegant, evocative, and easily recognizable for their quality and the skill with which she would add many types of clay and colors to a single piece.

As she aged, she began to lose her sight. She continued making pots even when she lost the ability to decorate them herself–by this point she had trained her husband and the next four generations of her family, who were able to complete her works. Her artistic traditions survive today in her descendants.

Today, her name invokes the memory of incredible craftswomanship, her work is shown across the country, and a crater in Mars has been named after her.

posts.body:
Jack Kevorkian

“Dying is not a crime”

Jack Kevorkian (1928-2011), sometimes called “Dr. Death” was an American pathologist who publicly fought for and provided the controversial right to die.

Born in Michigan to Armenian immigrants, Kevorkian was a child prodigy. He previously made waves developing ideas about death, against contemporary taboos.

In 1959, he argued that prisoners facing the death penalty ought to be allowed to opt-in to medical experimentation (under “complete anaesthesia”). He further argued for harvesting organs for death penalty inmates for transplant. Both of the ideas were unpopular and failed to manifest.

When working as a pathologist in 1993, Kevorkian successfully extracted blood from recently deceased corpses and transfused it into living patients. This was also not adopted by the wider medical community.

It was in 1989 that he performed his first physician-assisted suicide of a 54-year old woman with Alzheimer’s. His medical license was revoked as a result.

Undaunted, he assisted in the suicide of 130 terminally ill people. (n.b. this is “physician-assisted suicide”, where the patient is the one taking the final action. This is separate from “voluntary euthanasia”, where the doctor does it. Medical ethics and law still has debates over both of these.)

Kevorkian was tried for murder three times and was acquitted. The fourth time, the trial was declared a mistrial. The fifth time, however, he had performed voluntary euthanasia rather than physician-assisted suicide, and was charged with second-degree murder and the delivery of a controlled substance.

He was sentenced to serve 10-25 years, of which he served just over eight years. He died from a blood clot at the age of 83.

Kevorkian remains a controversial figure. According to medical historian Howard Markel, he was “was a major historical figure in modern medicine”. Derek Humphry, himself a proponent of the right to die, said he was, “too obsessed, too fanatical, in his interest in death and suicide to offer direction for the nation”.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

August 3rd, 1936 Jesse Owens wins the 100 meter dash at the Berlin Olympics.

He won four gold medals at the Olympics in Germany, the most successful athlete in those games. As a Black man, he was “single-handedly crushing Hitler’s myth of Aryan supremacy,” on their home turf.

posts.body:
Bà Triệu, the Vietnamese Warrior

“I’d like to ride storms, kill orcas in the open sea, drive out the aggressors, reconquer the country, undo the ties of serfdom, and never bend my back to be the concubine of whatever man.”

Lady Triệu (226-248 CE), as she is sometimes called in the West, was a 3rd-century Vietnamese warrior and freedom fighter.

At only 19 years of age, she led a military resistance of 1,000 fighters against Wu invaders. Her older brother was a headman who, after she rebuked his recommendation she settle down, supported her military efforts. After her brother’s death, she took over and led the army in 30 separate battles.

Sources described her as 9 feet tall with 3 feet long breasts, riding an elephant into battle.

The Wu Dynasty responded by sending its reinforcements to outnumber her army and their best general. Despite this, Bà Triệu held out for another half year of resistance. All told, she fought for four years, her entire adult life. At 23, rather than surrender, she killed herself on Tung Mountain.

Vietnamese independence continued to struggle, and the Vietnamese memory never forgot her. A folk hero, she features heavily in Vietnamese history (and is completely absent from Wu accounts, which focused on the rebel leaders they were able to bribe).

posts.body:
Enheduanna, the First Writer

Well, the first known writer. She was a Sumerian princess-priestess-poetess.

She lived from 2285-2250 BCE in Ur, Sumeria (modern-day Iraq). Her father was King Sargon the Great of Akkad, who unified many Sumerian city-states and was the first person in recorded history to rule an empire (probably–it depends on your precise definition of ‘empire’).

It was Sargon who appointed his daughter to High Priestess to help consolidate power in the city of Ur, in the southern part of the kingdom.

She served, and was called the wife of, Nanna, the Sumerian moon god. The name we now know her by reflects this: EN was the role of High Priestess and Nanna was the diety she served. However, many of her writings were for Inanna (later called Ishtar), the Queen goddess of love, beauty, sex, war, justice, and political power.

All told, Enheduanna composed 42 hymns that were spread and copied through the empire. She said,

“My king, something has been created that no one has created before.”

She also wrote 'Nin-Me-Sar-Ra’ (The Exaltation of Inanna), one of several personal devotions to Inanna that helped connect the goddess to Ishtar. It also details some events of Enheduanna’s life. It relates that she was expelled from Ur after a political rebellion against her father; she asked Nanna to intercede..

It’s not known how her life ends, but the Akkadian Empire started by her father lasted for a hundred years after her death, and her name and works remain famous across the world.


Temple Hymn 26

The Zabalam Temple Of Inanna

O house    wrapped in beams of light

wearing shining stone jewels    wakening great awe

sanctuary of pure Inanna

(where) divine powers the true me spread wide

Zabalam

shrine of the shining mountain

shrine that welcomes the morning light

she makes resound with desire

the Holy Woman grounds your hallowed chamber

with desire

your queen    Inanna of the sheepfold

that singular woman

the unique one

who speaks hateful words to the wicked

who moves among the bright shining things

who goes against rebel lands

and at twilight makes the firmament beautiful

all on her own

great daughter of Suen

pure Inanna

O house of Zabalam

has built this house on your radiant site

and placed her seat upon your dais
